text: how early were you aware of the
prominent position that you were in
yourself but also the the expectation
that might be on your shoulders as you
grew up
I don't remember not being aware
candidly my father was the governor of
Arkansas when I was born and I remember
you going around the state with him on
weekends and being in you know whether
it was Rogers or El Dorado or Magnolia
Arkansas people coming up to me and
saying you know oh you're the governor's
daughter or do you want to be governor
when you grow up and I would think you
know I'm three four you know I don't I
don't know what I want to do when I grow
up but I've always been aware of the
prominence of my parents as you put it
and also of some amorphous expectation
that I would also do something if not
political than something to make a
difference in the world you and your
mother Hillary have just announced an
initiative in to the tune of 80 million
dollars to try and stem the tide of
ivory poaching why is this important
this really is a human rights issue it's
a security issue it's an economic
empowerment issue so many of the things
that we really care about are bound up
in the question of ivory so when we
think about it as a security issue which
probably is somewhat surprising to
people I don't think people normally
think oh you know I'm buying an ivory
chopstick or Buddha you know there's
security implications to that purchase
but there really are you know we know
that the ivory trafficking is helping to
fund al-shabaab
the Lord's Resistance Army al Qaeda
North Africa needs so many of the most
destabilizing forces for African States
but also real threats to you know where
you live in the UK and like where I live
here in the United States let me ask you
about that another issue that you've
wanted to highlight maternal health tell
me why maternal health is a big big
thing for you
well it's a big issue to me because it
just seems like such a fundamental moral
issue to me I mean how can life and
death be so intimately connected
you know why are there still hundreds of
thousands of women
the year who died while pregnant or
while giving birth simply because they
don't have access to the prenatal care
that they need to the delivery care that
they need or the rights to not have to
get married and expect to be pregnant
before their bodies and their spirits
are ready to make those choices for
themselves and so for me I really think
that as my mom has said you the rights
of women and girls remain the unfinished
business of the 21st century
this this idea of wanting to do to give
something back to try and make a
contribution to making the world a
better place is that is that something
that you have ever regarded through the
prism of politics well when I was little
people would ask me you know are you
gonna grow from the governor one day my
visceral reaction was just no always and
then for a long time because I was oh
because I was a little kid or because
you know I loved space and I thought
that day I was definitely gonna be an
astronaut I mean it for all sorts of
reasons it was just kind of know for so
long and then as I've gotten older I
think it's really important who is in
the political arena who raises his or
her hand and runs for office
successfully and unsuccessfully and so
now that I believe that so strongly you
know it is something that I think about
but at this moment in time I love the
work I'm doing with the Clinton
Foundation I love my life and I'm
grateful that I live in a city and a
state in the country in which I strongly
support my elected leaders I believe in
their ethos I believe in their
competencies but at some point if any of
that were not true if I were
disappointed in my elected leaders and I
believed that I could make a
disproportionate positive difference if
I were to run for office I have to ask
an answer those questions
